title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by the panel that materially affected the decision, they may file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade. The Court of International Trade reviews binational panel determinations under the Tariff Act of 1930. The court examines legal and factual analysis to determine if any actions described have been established. Decisions of the court are binding on the parties involved. If a party files a notice of appeal, jurisdiction exclusively resides with the United States Court of International Trade. The jurisdiction for reviewing binational panel determinations under the Tariff Act of 1930 exclusively belongs to the United States Court of International Trade. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. The United States Court of International Trade has jurisdiction over reviewing binational panel determinations under the Tariff Act of 1930. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations of binational panels convened under NAFTA. Article 1904 of NAFTA has requested review under section 404A of the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act will apply to final determinations of binational panels under article 1904 of NAFTA published in the Federal Register after the enactment date of this Act.
